subject: question
msgSnippet: LAdies and Gents: I am on the prowl for some technical data.  I work for a project development company located in Pittsburgh.  We re currently doing a wireless
messageBody:
question

LAdies and Gents:
I am on the prowl for some technical data.  I work for a project development company located in Pittsburgh.  We're currently doing a wireless project in Pittsburgh with McKesson.  Does anyone know of any other local companies with the PIttsburgh-Ohio area that would be doing anything with Rational Rose, Junit, Ant, Etc.  Preferably wireless integration projects.  Please let me know.

Nicole Wilson
nwilson@...       


-----Original Message-----
From: Erik Meade [mailto:emeade@...]
Sent: Friday, January 25, 2002 9:06 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] JavaDocs (was Re: Re: junit.textui.TestRunner)


The JavaDocs found on source forge (and shipped with JUnit) are the APIs
that Kent and Erich think seriously about before changing.  These APIs
are a promise to the users.  As changes are made methods will be
deprecated for one version and then removed in the next.  Classes whose
JavaDocs are not included can be more volatile.

JUnit.org provides all the JavaDocs as a convince only.

Erik Meade
http://junit.org
emeade@...
 

> -----Original Message-----
>    Date: Tue, 22 Jan 2002 15:07:45 -0800
>    From: Shane Duan <sduan@...>
> Subject: Re: Re: junit.textui.TestRunner
>
> Ok.  Here is as far as I have seen.  I would be more than happy if I am
> proved to be wrong, since it is going to save me a lot of trouble also.
>
> In the JavaDoc, here is the list that I can see:
> ActiveTestSuite
> Assert
> AssertionFailedError
> ExceptionTestCase
> Protectable
> RepeatedTest
> Test
> TestCase
> TestDecorator
> TestFailure
> TestListener
> TestResult
> TestSetup
> TestSuite
>
> So, there is NOTHING about the TestRunner, or BaseTestRunner or any
> sort.  I remember I checked the JUnit.org page and it states that it is
> under IBM open source public license.  So I thought that the only thing
> I can be sure is to use ONLY the classes in the JavaDoc that comes with
> JUnit.
>
> Shane
>
